result.headline: New Jersey Could Be a Tough State for Chris Christie to Win
result.summary: The governor’s standing in his state has plummeted as complaints grow that he has spent too much time planning a presidential run and not enough addressing the state’s needs.
result.byline: By KATE ZERNIKE and NICK CORASANITI

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for president at Livingston High School in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

article.byline: By KATE ZERNIKE and NICK CORASANITI

print_information.edition: The New York Times on the Web

article.infobox: Follow The New York Times Politics and Washington on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the First Draft politics newsletter.
article.body:
The breakup has been a long time coming. For two years, he has spent more and more time away, openly flirting with others in what looked a lot like a trial separation. At home, he got an increasingly chilly reception.

Gov. Chris Christie’s entry into the presidential race moves his strained relationship with New Jersey voters into something looking a lot like a divorce. And it would probably be uncontested.

The governor’s standing in New Jersey has fallen so far that a poll last week showed his approval rating lower than that of Jon S. Corzine, the unpopular Democrat he unseated and still uses as a punching bag. Most voters dislike “everything about him,” the same survey found of Mr. Christie. Other polls show that most Republicans in the state do not think he has the temperament to be president.

The interim superintendent of the school district in his hometown, Livingston, where Mr. Christie entered the presidential race on Tuesday, skipped his announcement, saying Mr. Christie has been a “terrible governor.” Close friends and prominent Republicans in New Jersey keep defecting to the campaigns of other presidential candidates.

Mr. Christie, for his part, sounds like a spouse who is done trying.

Pressed by reporters on Friday about why he had not held a town-hall-style meeting in the state in six weeks, the governor said: “I got tired of it. I’ll just be honest with you: I got tired of it. So I didn’t do it.”

It did not go unnoticed that he had held such meetings in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina over the same six weeks.

He had always said he loved town-hall-style meetings in his home state for the chance to hear from real New Jerseyans. And yes, back in February — when he recommitted to his job, telling a town hall in Moorestown, “I care” — he had promised to do one a week.

“I did,” he said on Friday, when asked about that promise. “I got tired of it. I’m sorry.”

Mr. Christie has spent nearly half of his second term out of state, leaving New Jersey in the hands of his lieutenant governor, Kim Guadagno. Last week, she even stood in for him at an event at an addiction-recovery center that is one of Mr. Christie’s pet causes.

He also announced the departure of three longtime cabinet officials, leaving the state with an acting treasurer and an acting health commissioner, to go along with the acting attorney general, who has occupied the post since 2013. And there are three years left in Mr. Christie’s term.

“We’re getting pretty close to irreconcilable differences,” said Patrick Murray, the director of the Monmouth University Polling Institute. “What’s that phrase, ‘withholding of affection’? It really is a lot like that.”

Mr. Christie faced an uphill battle from the start, as a Republican in a largely Democratic state. But voters used to say they were proud that he was seen as a presidential contender. He made being from New Jersey — with its storied bluster — so much a part of his appeal that market research for tourism campaigns showed that he was what people outside the state most associated with it.

Now, New Jerseyans are more apt to complain that he has ignored the state’s pressing needs with his long preparation for a presidential campaign. Those who once saw his forceful style as strong leadership more often call it bullying. Those who used to credit him with straight talk often accuse him of breaking faith.

“He makes a deal, he makes a handshake, and he changes,” said Marty Goldberg, 90, as he entered a grocery store in Livingston, the affluent northern New Jersey suburb where Mr. Christie grew up. “That’s not how we do things.”

The complaint among New Jerseyans is particularly loud on pensions. Mr. Christie signed a law in 2011 requiring state employees to pay more toward their benefits, and in exchange, the state promised to make long-deferred payments. But after his budget went out of balance two years ago, he reneged on the payments.

Laurie Levy, a preschool teacher in Livingston who said she supported Mr. Christie in 2009, scoffs when she sees him in other states trumpeting his accomplishments in Trenton.

“He didn’t meet the budget that he was supposed to meet,” Ms. Levy said.

“I think he’s been absent from the state of New Jersey campaigning,” she added. “Or pretending not to be, but really, it’s campaigning.”

Walking the boardwalk in Seaside Heights, which was damaged by Hurricane Sandy, a storm that sent Mr. Christie’s approval rating soaring to 77 percent, Carmine Centanni said that he had voted for Mr. Christie because “he stood for standards that I had, that I liked.” But he said he now thinks of the governor as just another politician.

“He has done nothing for the state,” Mr. Centanni said.

There are still those who admire the governor, or at least identify with him: “He’s like me,” said Paul Kehler, 57, from Lawrenceville. “You think it, you say it, you know? Then you have to retract most of it afterwards, you have to pull your foot out of your mouth. But I like that approach, that no nonsense, this is how it is, this is how it’s going to be.”

Still, even among Republican donors, there are cracks in what was once Mr. Christie’s remarkable party discipline. Several prominent New Jersey Republicans, including one old friend of Mr. Christie’s, have lined up behind former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida in his run for president.

Joseph Schmuckler, who attended the University of Delaware with Mr. Christie, served on his transition team in 2009 and was nominated by him to the State Investment Council of New Jersey, has signed on as treasurer for the presidential campaign of Carly Fiorina.

“The presidency requires a certain demeanor and temperament and a certain leadership quality that talks, in my mind, to thoughtfulness and resolve,” said Hersh Kozlov, a lawyer in Cherry Hill who is raising money for Mr. Bush. “And I don’t think, as humorous as it may be, that some of the banter that Chris engages in with people is what I would expect or want for president of the United States.”

He recalled, in particular, Mr. Christie’s waving an ice cream cone at a teacher with whom he had exchanged words on the Jersey Shore. “That’s a terrible thing,” Mr. Kozlov said. “That’s not what I want in the leader of the free world.”

Mr. Christie seemed almost checked out last week when he announced the departure of the three cabinet officials. He gave one a $72,000-a-year position on a state board. He also announced the departure of the superintendent of the Newark schools, which the state has controlled for 20 years, and then said that he was returning the schools to local control. Only a year ago, he had rebuffed calls for local control, insisting that he was “the decider” when it came to Newark’s schools.

On Tuesday in Livingston, Mr. Christie talked about his family, his education, his accomplishments in New Jersey.

But his focus will be on New Hampshire, where a plane took him later in the day.

For New Jerseyans, his leave, for a week or so on the campaign trail, may feel more permanent.

“There was some hope that there would be an opportunity to turn things around,” said Krista Jenkins, the director of the PublicMind Poll at Fairleigh Dickinson University. “But once you announce that, despite the fact that you’re the governor of a troubled state, you’re now going to run for the presidency, from the perspective of the average voter, I think at that point you say, ‘Gee, I think you’re not interested in being governor of my state.’ ”

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for president at Livingston High School in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

100000003771603.headline: What Chris Christie Would Need to Do to Win
100000003771603.summary: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has entered the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Here is a look at what he would need to do if he hopes to win.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey at an event this month in Washington.

interactivegraphics.freeformbody:
1. The Coalition

    Mr. Christie’s voters are likely to come from the moderate wing of the Republican Party. While he opposes abortion rights, he has little natural connection to Christian conservatives. He is better suited to the business community and party activists who find his pugnacity appealing. A Christie voter is somebody who appreciates tough talk – but not tough talk about, say, unseating Supreme Court justices.

  2. The Map

    Mr. Christie's hopes begin – and could end – in New Hampshire. He is counting on fellow Northeasterners to warm to him in the same way they have taken to other presidential candidates who have a tell-it-like-it-is image. But he is hardly the only Republican relying on the state’s famously flinty voters to vault him into contention. If he does manage to win New Hampshire, he could emerge as a strong rival to candidates with similar followings, like Jeb Bush, as the race shifts to South Carolina and Nevada. And if he can fare well in those states, he could stay alive into March.

  3. The Message

    Mr. Christie is trying to turn his persona into something resembling a hybrid of style and substance: He is not only offering hard truths, but doing so on some of the nation’s most nettlesome challenges, like entitlements and education. The inference he hopes voters will draw is that only he will dare speak honestly about such matters. A secondary message to Republicans hungry to recapture the White House is that he won twice in a heavily Democratic state, did so with a multiracial coalition and could do nationally what he did in New Jersey.

  4. Why He Will Win

    Few politicians can match Mr. Christie’s charisma and knack for give-and-take. His skills are not to be found in a briefing book. He is particularly well suited for New Hampshire’s tradition of freewheeling town halls. If he can match his performances there with a few successful turns in televised debates, he could vault into contention.

  5. Why He Won't

    Mr. Christie’s politicking routine is compelling, but if it ultimately seems to be about him, and not the voters, his talent will be for naught. New Jersey has soured on him, more Republicans say they would not consider supporting him than any other candidate except Donald Trump, and he is not finding anywhere near the financial support he expected to secure after his landslide 2013 re-election. His political base in the New York-New Jersey area and his penchant for sound bites will earn him more attention than other also-rans, but will move few primary voters.

100000003772934.headline: Gov. Christie Announces Presidential Bid
100000003772934.summary: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced on Tuesday at his former high school in Livingston, N.J., that he is seeking the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for president at his former high school in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

100000003482816.headline: Who Is Running for President (and Who’s Not)?
100000003482816.summary: At least a dozen Republicans and a handful of Democrats have expressed an interest in running for their party’s 2016 presidential nomination.
100000003482816.byline: By WILSON ANDREWS, ALICIA PARLAPIANO and KAREN YOURISH

interactivegraphics.freeformbody:
Get updates via: Facebook | Twitter | First Draft politics newsletter

The democrats

Running

Clinton
Running
Sanders
Running
O'Malley
Running
Chafee
Running
Probably

Webb
Probably
Probably not

Biden
Probably not
Not running

Warren
Not running

The republicans

Running

Bush
Running
Cruz
Running
Paul
Running
Rubio
Running
Carson
Running
Fiorina
Running
Huckabee
Running
Santorum
Running
Pataki
Running
Graham
Running
Perry
Running
Trump
Running
Jindal
Running
Christie
Running
Probably

Walker
Probably
Kasich
Probably
Not running

Romney
Not running
Clinton
Running

Hillary Rodham Clinton

Former Secretary of State
“I’m running for president,” Mrs. Clinton said in a video.

Setting up shopLeased two floors of office space in Brooklyn for her headquarters.

Staffing UpMs. Clinton has built the largest campaign operation of any potential candidate so far, with Robby Mook, a veteran of her 2008 campaign, the leading contender for campaign manager.

Cutting tiesStepped down from the board of the Clinton Foundation in order to run for president.

What Clinton would need to do to win
Sanders
Running

Bernie Sanders

United States Senator
“After a year of travel, discussion and dialogue, I have decided to be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for president.”

Party alignmentThe independent senator, who calls himself a socialist, plans to run for president as a Democrat.

Recent appearancesHas visited early primary states like Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina to help him learn if he has the support to run.

What Sanders would need to do to win
O'Malley
Running

Martin O'Malley

Former Maryland governor
“We must save our country now. And we will do that by rebuilding the dream.”

Clinton jabMr. O'Malley derided the "politics of triangulation," echoing Barack Obama's 2008 campaign in a veiled jab at Mrs. Clinton's ostensibly poll-driven politics.

Staffing UpHired Bill Hyers, who most recently managed Bill de Blasio's mayoral campaign in New York, as a senior adviser to his PAC, "O'Say Can You See."

What O'Malley would need to do to win
Chafee
Running

Lincoln Chafee

Former Rhode Island governor
“Today, I am formally entering the race for the Democratic nomination for president.”

Iraq takes center stageA former Republican senator who cast the party's only vote against the Iraq war, Mr. Chafee argues that Ms. Clinton's vote to authorize the war should disqualify her from the presidency.

What Chafee would need to do to win
Webb
Probably

Jim Webb

Former United States Senator
“I'm seriously looking at the possibility of running for president.”

Testing the WatersIn November, became the first candidate in either party to announce a presidential exploratory committee.

Biden
Probably not

Joseph R. Biden Jr.

Vice President
“Honest to God, I haven’t made up my mind.”

Taking his timeWhile Mr. Biden said that "there is a chance" that he would take on Hillary Clinton, he will likely wait until summer to decide.

Visiting key statesPromoted the White House's economic policies in the early caucus and primary states of Iowa and South Carolina.

Warren
Not running

Elizabeth Warren

United States Senator
“I am not running for president. You want me to put an exclamation point at the end?”

New book"A Fighting Chance" came out in April 2014.

Bush
Running

Jeb Bush

Former Florida governor
“I will take nothing and no one for granted. I will run with heart. I will run to win."

Early moneyMr. Bush appears to have an early lead in fundraising, using his "Right to Rise" super PAC to raise money at high-dollar events.

Staffing UpDavid Kochel, a Republican strategist based in Iowa, joined Mr. Bush's PAC as a senior strategist and is in line to serve as national campaign manager.

Cutting TiesResigned from outside corporate and nonprofit board positions and sold stakes in his remaining businesses.

What Bush would need to do to win
Cruz
Running

Ted Cruz

United States Senator
Mr. Cruz posted on Twitter, “I’m running for President and I hope to earn your support!”

Getting an early startBegan his candidacy with a round of TV appearances and swings through New Hampshire and Iowa.

Setting up shopOpened his presidential campaign headquarters in Houston.

What Cruz would need to do to win
Paul
Running

Rand Paul

United States Senator
“I am running for president to return our country to the principles of liberty and limited government,” Mr. Paul wrote on his website.

Straw poll winner againMr. Paul won the straw poll at CPAC for the third straight year, and his speech was greeted with shouts of "President Paul!".

Staffing UpHired Chip Englander, who managed Bruce Rauner's successful campaign for governor of Illinois, as his campaign manager.

What Paul would need to do to win
Rubio
Running

Marco Rubio

United States Senator
Mr. Rubio announced his candidacy in a call to donors on April 13.

Drawing a contrastIn his announcement speech, Mr. Rubio cast himself as a forward-looking, next-generation leader. “Too many of our leaders and our ideas are stuck in the 20th century,” he said.

Staffing UpHired Jim Merrill, who previously ran Mitt Romney's primary campaigns in New Hampshire. J. Warren Tompkins, a former business partner of of Terry Sullivan, an adviser to Mr. Rubio, is expected to oversee a "super PAC" supporting his candidacy.

What Rubio would need to do to win
Carson
Running

Ben Carson

Retired Neurosurgeon
“I’m announcing my candidacy for president of the United States.”

Recent appearancesSpoke to a groggy crowd in a not-so-prime-time speech at CPAC.

Campaign ContributionsThe National Draft Ben Carson for President Committee had raised some $12 million as of mid-January, enough to show there is interest in his candidacy.

What Carson would need to do to win
Fiorina
Running

Carly Fiorina

Former Business Executive
“I think I’m the best person for the job because I understand how the economy actually works.”

Recent appearancesMs. Fiorina was politely received at CPAC, where she defended the Israeli prime minister and attacked Hillary Clinton.

Staffing UpHired Sarah Isgur Flores, the former deputy communications director for the Republican National Committee, to work for her super PAC, "Unlocking Potential."

What Fiorina would need to do to win
Huckabee
Running

Mike Huckabee

Former Arkansas governor
“I announce that I am a candidate for president of the United States of America.”

New committeeIowa operative Nick Ryan has started a super PAC supporting Mr. Huckabee, called "Pursuing America's Greatness."

Severing tiesHe said leaving his show at Fox News was "a pretty good indication" that he had a presidential run in mind.

What Huckabee would need to do to win
Santorum
Running

Rick Santorum

Former United States Senator
Mr. Santorum wrote in a tweet, “Today I announce my candidacy for President of the United States!”

Recent appearancesMr. Santorum had the spot after Rand Paul at the CPAC convention, and his tough-talking foreign-policy speech was delivered as Mr. Paul's followers exited.

Criticizing RivalsReferring to potential contenders Senator Rand Paul and Senator Ted Cruz, Mr. Santorum said, "Do we really want somebody who’s a bomb thrower, with no track record of any accomplishments?”

What Santorum would need to do to win
Pataki
Running

George Pataki

Former New York governor
“I am a candidate for the Republican nomination for president of the United States.”

New committeeLaunched a super PAC called "We the People, Not Washington" to prepare the way for a presidential run.

What Pataki would need to do to win
Graham
Running

Lindsey Graham

United States Senator
“I want to be president to protect our nation that we all love so much from all threats foreign and domestic.”

New committeeSet up a political committee called "Security Through Strength" to pay for expenses while exploring a run.

Visiting key statesSpent two days in Iowa in February and returned in March for an agricultural policy forum attended by several fellow potential candidates.

What Graham would need to do to win
Perry
Running

Rick Perry

Former Texas governor
“I am running for the presidency of the United States of America.”

Staffing upTurning to Austin Barbour, a Mississippi-based lobbyist and political operative, to head a "super PAC" to support his campaign.

Boosting His RecordAs his 14-year run as governor of Texas came to end, he has traveled the country, including Iowa, to promote his accomplishments.

What Perry would need to do to win
Trump
Running

Donald Trump

Real estate mogul
“Ladies and gentleman, I am officially running for president of the United States.”

A place on stageMr. Trump's position in the polls will likely earn him a spot in the Republican debates, which are to be limited to 10 participants.

What Trump would need to do to win
Jindal
Running

Bobby Jindal

Louisiana governor
Mr. Jindal announced on Wednesday that he is running for president.

Courting conservativesSpoke at the CPAC conferene, to a room noticeably less enthusiastic than it was moments earlier, during Gov. Scott Walker's speech.

Outside supportBackers of the governor have set up "Believe Again," a super PAC to support a 2016 run.

What Jindal would need to do to win
Christie
Running

Chris Christie

New Jersey governor
“I am now ready to fight for the people of the United States of America.”

Visiting key statesAccording to his own count, Mr. Christie has made more than a dozen trips to Iowa since 2010, including one in January to speak at the Iowa Freedom Summit, a grass-roots gathering of the party’s more conservative base.

Foreign credentialsWent on a three-day trade mission to Britain, just months after similar visits to Mexico and to Canada.

What Christie would need to do to win
Walker
Probably

Scott Walker

Wisconsin governor
“My personal process is I have to feel like it's a calling, particularly for the time and the effort and the impact it has on family and friends.”

Building infrastructureBecame the first candidate to open a campaign office in Iowa. Mr. Walker has brought on Rick Wiley, a former Republican National Committee political director, to build a political operation.

New committeeStarted "Our American Revival," a 527 group that can accept unlimited contributions, to pay for campaign-related activities in advance of an official announcement.

Kasich
Probably

John Kasich

Ohio governor
“I'm pretty qualified for this kind of a job.”

New committeeLaunched "New Day for America", a tax-exempt nonprofit committee, to raise money and gauge support for a run.

Visiting key statesHas made recent trips to the early primary states of New Hampshire and South Carolina.

Romney
Not running

Mitt Romney

2012 Republican presidential nominee
“I did not want to make it more difficult for someone else to emerge who may have a better chance of becoming the president.”

Initial OutreachAfter announcing to a group of New York-based donors that he wanted to explore another presidential campaign, Mr. Romney reached out to former staff, supporters and top Republicans and decided against a run.

Mr. Santorum wrote in a tweet, “Today I announce my candidacy for President of the United States!”

Recent appearancesMr. Santorum had the spot after Rand Paul at the CPAC convention, and his tough-talking foreign-policy speech was delivered as Mr. Paul's followers exited.

Criticizing RivalsReferring to potential contenders Senator Rand Paul and Senator Ted Cruz, Mr. Santorum said, "Do we really want somebody who’s a bomb thrower, with no track record of any accomplishments?”

What Santorum would need to do to win
Pataki
Running

George Pataki

Former New York governor
“I am a candidate for the Republican nomination for president of the United States.”

New committeeLaunched a super PAC called "We the People, Not Washington" to prepare the way for a presidential run.

What Pataki would need to do to win
Graham
Running

Lindsey Graham

United States Senator
“I want to be president to protect our nation that we all love so much from all threats foreign and domestic.”

New committeeSet up a political committee called "Security Through Strength" to pay for expenses while exploring a run.

Visiting key statesSpent two days in Iowa in February and returned in March for an agricultural policy forum attended by several fellow potential candidates.

What Graham would need to do to win
Perry
Running

Rick Perry

Former Texas governor
“I am running for the presidency of the United States of America.”

Staffing upTurning to Austin Barbour, a Mississippi-based lobbyist and political operative, to head a "super PAC" to support his campaign.

Boosting His RecordAs his 14-year run as governor of Texas came to end, he has traveled the country, including Iowa, to promote his accomplishments.

What Perry would need to do to win
Trump
Running

Donald Trump

Real estate mogul
“Ladies and gentleman, I am officially running for president of the United States.”

A place on stageMr. Trump's position in the polls will likely earn him a spot in the Republican debates, which are to be limited to 10 participants.

What Trump would need to do to win
Jindal
Running

Bobby Jindal

Louisiana governor
Mr. Jindal announced on Wednesday that he is running for president.

Courting conservativesSpoke at the CPAC conferene, to a room noticeably less enthusiastic than it was moments earlier, during Gov. Scott Walker's speech.

Outside supportBackers of the governor have set up "Believe Again," a super PAC to support a 2016 run.

What Jindal would need to do to win
Christie
Running

Chris Christie

New Jersey governor
“I am now ready to fight for the people of the United States of America.”

Visiting key statesAccording to his own count, Mr. Christie has made more than a dozen trips to Iowa since 2010, including one in January to speak at the Iowa Freedom Summit, a grass-roots gathering of the party’s more conservative base.

Foreign credentialsWent on a three-day trade mission to Britain, just months after similar visits to Mexico and to Canada.

What Christie would need to do to win
Walker
Probably

Scott Walker

Wisconsin governor
“My personal process is I have to feel like it's a calling, particularly for the time and the effort and the impact it has on family and friends.”

Building infrastructureBecame the first candidate to open a campaign office in Iowa. Mr. Walker has brought on Rick Wiley, a former Republican National Committee political director, to build a political operation.

New committeeStarted "Our American Revival," a 527 group that can accept unlimited contributions, to pay for campaign-related activities in advance of an official announcement.

Kasich
Probably

John Kasich

Ohio governor
“I'm pretty qualified for this kind of a job.”

New committeeLaunched "New Day for America", a tax-exempt nonprofit committee, to raise money and gauge support for a run.

Visiting key statesHas made recent trips to the early primary states of New Hampshire and South Carolina.

Romney
Not running

Mitt Romney

2012 Republican presidential nominee
“I did not want to make it more difficult for someone else to emerge who may have a better chance of becoming the president.”

Initial OutreachAfter announcing to a group of New York-based donors that he wanted to explore another presidential campaign, Mr. Romney reached out to former staff, supporters and top Republicans and decided against a run.
interactivegraphics.leadin: More than a dozen Republicans and a handful of Democrats have expressed an interest in running for their party's 2016 presidential nomination.

100000003165138.headline: First Draft
100000003165138.summary: First Draft provides fast-paced and comprehensive coverage of politics and elections by The New York Times.

interactivegraphics.freeformbody: Political News, Now.
interactivegraphics.freeform_body: Political News, Now.

100000003771596.headline: Chris Christie Announces Run, Pledging ‘Truth’ About Nation’s Woes
100000003771596.summary: New Jersey’s governor faces many hurdles in the 2016 race for president. But if his record seems wobbly, he willl have to use his most prodigious asset: his personality.

promotional_media.headline: Gov. Christie Announces Presidential Bid
promotional_media.summary: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced on Tuesday at his former high school in Livingston, N.J., that he is seeking the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for president at his former high school in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

100000003773150.headline: The Chat: Chris Christie’s Announcement Speech, Instantly Analyzed
100000003773150.summary: Chris Christie cast himself as an anti-Washington candidate and as a strong leader for a nation craving authority after years of fecklessness and weakness.
100000003773150.byline: By PATRICK HEALY and MAGGIE HABERMAN

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

100000003771532.headline: Chris Christie on the Issues
100000003771532.summary: The governor is leery of deals with Iran and Cuba, says one immigration solution is a clampdown on illegal hiring, and opposes same-sex marriage and Common Core.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie at a town hall meeting in Fair Lawn, N.J., in March.

100000003771588.headline: Things You May Not Know About Chris Christie
100000003771588.summary: Gov. Chris Christie is, to many New Jerseyans, the very definition of an open book. But his biography still manages to contain a few surprises.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, this month.

100000003773071.headline: Chris Christie’s Path to Relevance
100000003773071.summary: Although his campaign is a long shot, he could nonetheless be a big influence in the Republican primary fight. Here’s how.

caption.full: Chris Christie on Tuesday announcing his intention to run for president. He was at the high school in Livingston, N.J., where he was class president.

100000003773247.headline: Timing of Christie’s Announcement Has Fund-Raising Advantages
100000003773247.summary: Though Chris Christie announced his presidential campaign on Tuesday it will be more than three months before rival candidates, the press, and potential supporters know whether he has had any fund-raising success.

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey acknowledged supporters as he formally announced his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination in Livingston, N.J., on Tuesday.

100000003773195.headline: Chris Christie’s Town Hall Bluntness to Be Tested
100000003773195.summary: Chris Christie once again deploys his bluntness to the home state crowd. Will it play elsewhere?

caption.full: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced his presidential bid in Livingston, N.J.
